<!channel> I've just deployed a new version to <http://demo.offcourse.io|demo.offcourse.io>. This is an important version, since it's probably (hopefully) the last before public launch. 

Noticable new features and fixes are:

- Separate sign up / sign in flow (combined flow was confusing)
- 404 pages for not found resources (for <@U0ARRNM3R>)
- Default Avatars for users
- Fixed the Get Url button (for <@U177W7XH8>)

As always with the demo version, all persistent save functionality is disabled. Now going to go back to the backend, to make sure I get most of the bugs out of these flows as well...

<!channel> another two weeks have passed, so I just pushed a new release on all environments. Major new features:
- Video Embeds (youtube, vimeo)
- Fork Flow

Saving of forks and statuses are disabled for now (makes live easier for me...)

I'd like to hear your feedback, especially on the latter! Next up: caching and persistent user sessions
These are my POVs though – if someone disagrees, lmk.

- feedback/suggestions
- ! necessary before launch

- ! upon reload, I want to stay signed in (people will think the platform is broken, when it’s not)
- ! I want like to see at least part the basic web development course on there <@U177W7XH8>, how far are you with your edits? (the content needs to make sense)
- ! I’m missing a time out message for when the resource fails to load after for example, 10 seconds Maybe we should say something like “The resource is taking too long to load. Open original instead” with a direct link? (we don’t want to be dependent onto the embedding service) 
- ! 404-message for when a link is broken or something else that is not a time out (again, we want to keep people engaged even if the embedding service doesn’t work)
- !  the “get URL” button doesn’t give me the link for the card, but for the entire platform. Fix or fade out button for now (it doesn’t make sense now)
- ! same goes for social buttons (ditto)
-  ! the platform doesn’t do anything when I click my name. Maybe select just my courses? Or otherwise don’t display my name (again, people might think the platform is broken)

- Firefox doesn’t work properly, but isn’t a deal breaker
- I would like to see a different lay out of the resource page, but that’s on my list with <@U17C0L2VA>, it’s not strictly necessary for launch
- tags aren’t 100% correct yet, but not a deal breaker for me
Love how the development is going so fast now and we're nearly there :slightly_smiling_face: Here's my feedback!

Let me know with features and fixes are absolutely necessary before we can go live. Thanks, JH
<@U0D6EPESC> sounds great - will have a look

<!channel>: There is a new version that you can check out. This one is more or less feature complete, except for the fact that I (for the moment) turned off saving to the back-end. Everything else that we set as target works now:
- Progress Tracking
- Course Creation
- Edit Course
- Authentication

For this version, I've chosen to roughly follow the forking and tracking flow that Pascal and Charlotte suggested last year. I must honestly say, that I am not entirely sure this works. Forking and tracking are now implicit actions, meaning that you start tracking your progress the moment you click a checkbox, and that you fork a course when you push edit.

In my opinion, this works for tracking, but not for forking. It's too implicit, meaning that the user does not realize what just happened. 

Anyways, I love to hear what your thoughts on this are. I definitely want to talk about this (and the feature roadmap) on our team day coming Tuesday. Hope you can all have a look at it before then. (<@U17C0L2VA> and <@U0ARRNM3R> in particular)

Also, I have created a new demo environment. This one is for <@U3MRJ1CDN> and <@U0ARRNM3R> in particular, to show to potential customers and partners. This environment, won't persist (save to the server) the courses that you create. That means, it's ideal to demonstrate features without 'littering' our production environment.

A short overview and explanation of our environments:

<http://nightly.offcourse.io|nightly.offcourse.io> - unstable, mainly for me (and hopefully other future devs) to deploy new features too.
<http://edge.offcourse.io|edge.offcourse.io> - mostly stable. This environment is to test new features before we move them to the production environment
<http://platform.offcourse.io|platform.offcourse.io> - stable, but currently inactive, the production environment. I expect too push this one live in two to three weeks
<http://demo.offcourse.io|demo.offcourse.io> - stable, see explanation above

At the moment, the same version is deployed to all envs except platform. Don't count on this to stay this way. Probably will not be try tomorrow already :wink:

attachments.title: Apple releases Classroom iPad app version 2.0 w/ ability to manually create classes & more
attachments.text:
Alongside public releases for iOS 10.3, macOS 10.12.4, watchOS 3.2, and tvOS 10.2 today, Apple has officially released version 2.0 of its Classroom app for iPad previously in beta.

Version 2 of the app brings a number of new features including the ability to create classes within the app and invite nearby students. That means that it will no longer require a Mobile Device Management setup to configure classes, making it easier for smaller organizations without IT assistance to use the app:
With Classroom 2.0, you can now set up your own classes manually, if your school isn’t configuring iPad for classroom use with MDM….If you have manually created your class, you can now invite your students to join. Select Add and give the invitation code to your students.

The app also gains the ability to share documents and links over AirDrop, a faster method that will replace the old Share Extension the app used previously. That feature works both ways, so both students and teachers can share links and documents back and forth with one another (as pictured in the example above):
Classroom 2.0 provides an easy way to share files with your students, such as worksheets, presentations, or photos and videos.
Lastly, the update adds an option for teachers to mute audio on student devices.
Video walkthrough

Subscribe to 9to5Mac on YouTube for more videos
To accompany the release today, Apple has an updated Getting Started with Classroom 2.0 teacher’s guide for the app that details new features and how to use them.
The updated Classroom app for iPad, version 2.0, is available for free on the App Store now.

What’s New in Version 2.0
• Create classes within Classroom and invite nearby students to join
• Share documents and links to student devices via AirDrop (replaces the Classroom Share Extension)
• Students can share documents and links with their teacher via AirDrop
• Mute audio on student devices
attachments.fallback: 9to5Mac Link: Apple releases Classroom iPad app version 2.0 w/ ability to manually create classes & more

text: Amazon launches Chime, a video conferencing and communications service for business. <http://google.com/newsstand/s/CBIwz7inpTQ>

attachments.title: Amazon launches Chime, a video conferencing and communications service for business
attachments.text:
Amazon has taken the wraps off of its own Skype competitor. Chime is a new video conferencing and communications from AWS that’s focused on business users.
Beyond VoIP calling and video messaging, Chime includes virtual meetings, allowing users to host or join a remote meeting through the service. Pricing starts at $2.50 per user per month on the lowest end, with a higher tier plan of $15 per user which includes video and screen-sharing among other features. There is a basic option available for free but that is limited to video calls and chat rooms between two users.
Chime is available for Windows, MacOS, iOS, and Android devices.
TechCrunch first reported that Amazon was planning this new service in November, when we wrote that the firm had acquired patents and staff from San Francisco-based Biba Systems, a startup behind video messaging apps aimed at business users.
The move is not only an alternative to communication services like Skype for business or Google Hangouts, but it is also takes AWS into the space of virtual meeting management, where companies like GoToMeeting and Cisco (WebEx) are the best known players.
“It’s pretty hard to find people who actually like the technology they use for meetings today. Most meeting applications or services are hard to use, deliver bad audio and video, require constant switching between multiple tools to do everything they want, and are way too expensive,” Gene Farrell, Vice President of enterprise applications at AWS, said in a statement.
AWS is already a formidable player in cloud services, as TechCrunch enterprise reporter Ron Miller explained this week, but Chime pushes it into the services space to help strengthen its grip on customers as competition increases. Microsoft, Google and even new entrants like Alibaba are making big pushes to nab customers from AWS, which remains a key performer for Amazon financially.
attachments.fallback: TechCrunch Link: Amazon launches Chime, a video conferencing and communications service for business
